revisions.rev:
{{Infobox sports season | title = Euroleague 2010â11 | league = [[Euroleague|Turkish Airlines Euroleague]] | sport = [[Basketball]] | logo = | logo_size = | caption = | duration = | attendance = | season =Regular Season | season_champs = | MVP ={{flagicon|GRC}} [[Dimitris Diamantidis]] | MVP_link = | top_scorer ={{flagicon|SRB}} [[Igor RakoÄeviÄ]] ([[Efes Pilsen S.K.|Efes Pilsen]]) | playoffs = | playoffs_link = | playoffs_MVP = | finals =Final Four | finals_link =Euroleague 2010â11 Final Four | finals_champ ={{flagicon|GRE}} [[Panathinaikos BC|Panathinaikos]] | finals_runner-up ={{flagicon|Israel}} [[Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]] | finals_MVP ={{flagicon|GRC}} [[Dimitris Diamantidis]] ([[Panathinaikos BC|Panathinaikos]]) | finals_MVP_link = Euroleague Final Four MVP | seasonslist = | seasonslistnames = Euroleague | prevseason_link = 2009â10 Euroleague | prevseason_year = 2009â10 | nextseason_link = 2011â12 Euroleague Basketball | nextseason_year = 2011â12 }} The '''Turkish Airlines Euroleague 2010â11''' was the 11th season of the modern era of [[Euroleague Basketball]] and the first under the title [[sponsorship]] of [[Turkish Airlines]]. Including the competition's previous incarnation as the [[FIBA Europe]] Champions Cup, this was the 54th season of the premier competition for European men's clubs. The format featured 24 teams, beginning with Game 1 of the first qualifying round on [[September 21]], [[2010]], and culminating at the [[Euroleague 2010â11 Final Four|Final Four]] in the [[Palau Sant Jordi]], [[Barcelona]].{{cite web |url=http://www.euroleague.net/news/i/73753/180 |title=2011 Euroleague Final Four set for Barcelona |accessdate=15 July 2010}} It was won by the [[Athens|Athenian]] club [[Panathinaikos BC|Panathinaikos]] (6th title), who defeated [[Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.|Maccabi Electra]] of [[Tel Aviv]] in the championship game of [[May 8]], [[2011]].{{cite web |url=http://www.euroleague.net/main/results/showgame/report?gamecode=189 |title=Game report:Maccabi Electra vs Panathinaikos |accessdate=8 May 2011}} [[Mens Sana Basket|Mens Sana]] of [[Siena]], competing as ''Montepaschi'' after the name of their principal sponsor, finished 3rd by holding off [[Real Madrid Baloncesto|Real Madrid]] in the third-place game.{{cite web |url=http://www.euroleague.net/main/results/showgame/report?phasetypecode=FF&gamecode=188&gamenumber=23 |title=Game report: Real Madrid vs Montepaschi Sienna|accessdate=8 May 2011}} At individual level the season was marked by [[Dimitris Diamantidis]] of Panathinaikos. Not only did the [[Greeks|Greek]] [[point guard]] lift the trophy for the third time in five years and receive the Final 4 MVP award, but he also became the first ever to win three end-of-season awards: Euroleague MVP, Best Defender and All-Euroleague First Team.{{cite web |url=http://www.euroleague.net/news/i/85423/180 |title=MVP Diamantidis heads 2010-11 All-Euroleague First Team |accessdate=8 May 2011}} ==Teams== {| border="1" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:0.5em;background: #F9F9F9; border: 1px #AAA solid;border-collapse: collapse;" !rowspan=1|Country 2009â10]] ==Draw== The draws for the 2010â11 Turkish Airlines Euroleague was held on Thursday, July 8 at [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]]. The draws began at 11:15 local time ([[Central European Time|CET]]) and determined the qualifying-round matchups and regular-season groups for the Euroleague, as well as the qualifying rounds for the Eurocup and the regular-season for the EuroChallenge. Teams were organised into six pots of four teams. Two teams from the same country cannot coincide in the same Regular Season group, except for Spain that has five teams participating in the competition. {| class="wikitable" width=98% |- !width=16%| '''Pot 1''' !width=16%| '''Pot 2''' !width=16%| '''Pot 3''' !width=16%| '''Pot 4''' !width=16%| '''Pot 5''' !width=16%| '''Pot 6''' |- | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[PBC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]]

{{flagicon|RUS}} [[BC Khimki Moscow Oblast|BC Khimki]] (QR B) |} ==Qualifying rounds== {{main|Euroleague 2010â11 qualifying rounds}} The Qualifying Rounds consisted of three rounds, QR1, QR2 and QR3. The rounds were played in home and away series. {{:Euroleague 2010â11 qualifying rounds}} ==Regular season== The Regular Season began on 18 October 2010 with [[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]] hosting [[Real Madrid Baloncesto|Real Madrid]] and ended on 23 December 2010. If teams are level on record at the end of the Regular Season, tiebreakers are applied in the following order: # Head-to-head record. # Head-to-head point differential. # Point differential during the Regular Season. # Points scored during the regular season. # Sum of quotients of points scored and points allowed in each Regular Season match. {| class="wikitable" |+ Key to colors |- | style="background: #ccffcc;" |      |Top four places in each group advanced to Top 16 |} ===Group A=== {{main|Euroleague 2010â11 Regular Season Group A}} {{:Euroleague 2010â11 Regular Season Group A}} ===Group B=== {{main|Euroleague 2010â11 Regular Season Group B}} {{:Euroleague 2010â11 Regular Season Group B}} ===Group C=== {{main|Euroleague 2010â11 Regular Season Group C}} {{:Euroleague 2010â11 Regular Season Group C}} ===Group D=== {{main|Euroleague 2010â11 Regular Season Group D}} {{:Euroleague 2010â11 Regular Season Group D}} ==Top 16== The 16 qualified teams were drawn into four groups with four teams. The matches were played between January 19 and March 3, the top two teams of every group advanced to the playoffs. The draw took place on 4 January 2011 at [[Barcelona]] at 13:00 CET, and was streamed live on the Euroleague's official website.{{citeweb|url=http://www.euroleague.net/news/i/80398/180|title=Top 16 Draw set for January 4 in Barcelona|date=2010-12-16|work=euroleague.net|accessdate=2010-12-23}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Key to colors |- | style="background: #ccffcc;" |      |Top two places in each
